Management of Children Who Are Not Brought to Appointments / MSEPO-20202/1.0

Introduction
This policy is to be used in conjunction with the Organisation's Patient Access Policy.

The purpose of this policy is to ensure the effective management, safety and well- being of children and young people identified as having missed outpatient appointments as offered within MSE, being under the care of either paediatric or adult services.
This policy only relates to routine appointments. When dealing with urgent or emergency situations the practitioner or clinical team can decide to bypass these procedures.

This policy has been developed to identify and follow up children and young people who are not brought to/did not attend an outpatient appointment or whose appointments are cancelled by their parent/carer.

Missed appointments (and non-engagement) with health professionals are often recurring themes within many Practice Learning Reviews (formerly serious case reviews). The significance of a missed appointment being two fold, one as to how the child's care is being neglected by the parents and also the confusing effect it has on practitioners especially when non-attendance is intermittent.

The National Service Framework for Children Young People and Maternity Services (Core Standards 2004) state that “children or young people failing to attend clinic appointments following referral from their general practitioners or other professionals may trigger concern given that they are reliant on their parent/carer to take them to their appointment. Failure to attend can be an indicator of a family's vulnerability.”
In view of this and the need to effectively manage clients who are not brought to appointments this policy has been produced to ensure a co-ordinated and consistent response.
Scope
This policy sets out the key principles that all staff and workers working across MSE should be complying with safeguarding children, young people and adults at risk of harm or abuse.

This policy applies to all employees and workers of the MSE group, including seconders into and out of the organisation, volunteers, students, honorary appointees, trainees, contractors, and temporary workers, including locum doctors and those working on a bank or agency contract.
For ease of reference, all employees and workers who fall under these groups will be uniformly referred to as “staff” in this document.

This policy applies to all areas within the Mid and South Essex Foundation NHS Trust Group for which children and young people under the age of 18 years receive appointments and to any instances when a child/young person is not brought to an appointment/does not attend appointment OR whose appointment is cancelled by their parent/carer.
Definitions

table_items.text: A child protection plan is a plan drawn up by the local authority. It sets out how the child can be kept safe, how things can be made better for the family and what support they will need.
CIN Plan - Child in Need Plan

Children defined under Section 17 of The Children's Act (1989) as those whose vulnerability is such that they are unlikely to reach or maintain a satisfactory level of health or development, or their health or development would be significantly impaired without the provision of services. Disabled children are also included in this category (The Children's Act (1989) S17d).
Local Safeguarding Children Partnerships (LSCP) formerly Local Safeguarding Children Boards (LSCB)

A multi-agency forum for developing, monitoring and reviewing local child protection policies and procedures and where necessary conducting Serious Case Reviews. N.B Essex Safeguarding board has retained the ESCB title but acknowledges the revised arrangements.

Looked After Child now Child Looked After - The term Children Looked After (Children in Care) has a specific legal meaning based on the Children Act, 1989. A child is looked after by a local authority if he or she has been provided with accommodation for a continuous period of more than 24 hours, in the circumstances set out in Sections 20 and 21 of the Children Act, 1989, or is placed in the care of a local authority by virtue of an order made under part IV of the Act.
Mid and South Essex University Hospitals Group ; Services provided by Basildon, Broomfield (Mid Essex) and Southend hospitals
Parental responsibility (PR) is defined as ‘In England and

Wales, if the parents of a child are married to each other at the time of the birth, or if they have jointly adopted a child, then they both have parental responsibility. Parents do not lose parental responsibility if they divorce, and this applies to both the resident and the non-resident parent'. This is not automatically the case for unmarried parents. According to current law, a mother always has parental responsibility for her child. A father, however, has this responsibility only if he is married to the mother when the child is born or has acquired legal responsibility for his child through one of these three routes: (From 1 December 2003) by jointly registering the birth of the child with the mother. By a parental responsibility agreement with the mother. By a parental responsibility order, made by a court. Parental responsibility can only be lost where: In the case of parents their child is adopted. In the case of a person having acquired parental responsibility through a court order that order later being revoked by the court. In the case of a local authority with care order and the court later revoking the care order. In the case of a guardian where the court appoints another guardian

The ill treatment or the impairment of health or development. This includes for example impairment caused by seeing or hearing the mistreatment of another. “Development” means physical, emotional, behavioural or social development. “Health” includes both physical and mental health. “Ill treatment” includes sexual abuse as well as other forms of ill- treatment that are not physical.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Clinical Governance Committee duties are:
Clinical Governance Committee monitors compliance with safeguarding;
Children policies and processes;
Site Safeguarding Children Committees / Operational meetings oversee all operational safeguarding children activity including training compliance and adherence to policies;
The Group Integrated Child and Adult Safeguarding Committee is a strategic meeting to: Check and challenge that MSE systems and processes are fit for

purpose to safeguard vulnerable individuals, focus on all services but not be operational, oversee CQC requirements and facilitate discussion relating to external strategic issues that may impact on the Mid and South Essex Foundation NHS Trust Group.
Chief Executive as Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust.
Director of Nursing/Medical Director – The Director of Nursing and the Medical Director will be corporately responsible for the implementation of this policy. This includes:
When the policy is reviewed and updated incorporating the time frame for the process to be undertaken;
Reporting into the necessary governance committees;
Ensuring that MSE provides/supports the training for staff to discharge their responsibilities and that there is an appropriate competency framework to support this.
4.3.1  The Director of Nursing at SUH also holds the executive lead in relation to Safeguarding Children.

Heads of Nursing/Head of Midwifery/Matrons/Heads of Departments/Service Managers/Department Managers – are responsible for the implementation of this policy at department level. This includes: Identifying training needs and ensuring staff attend training; assessing service requirements against what the service is delivering.

Designated, Named Professionals and the Safeguarding Team - Lead personnel have a key role in championing the importance of safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children throughout the MSE group.
MSE Safeguarding Teams:
Designated doctor;
Named doctor;
Group named nurse, safeguarding children;
Group named midwife, safeguarding children;
Specialist nurses, safeguarding children;
Specialist safeguarding midwives;
Group Associate Director and Deputy Director Safeguarding.
Other professionals who are able to provide advice and information in relation specifically to safeguarding issues are:
Paediatric Liaison Health Visitor;
Head of Paediatrics;
Head of Midwifery.

4.7.1  In the absence of the above professional, advice can be sought from senior paediatric professionals; on-call paediatric registrar and on-call Paediatrician for Child Protection via switchboard and, in addition, advice can be sought by the relevant Social Care Department.
Duties of all MSE staff (substantive or non-substantive, including volunteers) must be aware of and adhere to the Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Safeguarding Procedures.

4.8.1 Safeguarding is each individual employee's responsibility as set out in Working Together to Safeguarding Children (2018) and the Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Interagency Child Protection and Safeguarding Procedures (2019). “All those who come into contact with children and families in their everyday work, including people who do not have a specific role in relation to child protection, have a duty to safeguard and promote the welfare of children” (What To Do If You Are Worried A Child Is Being Abused 2006).
4.8.2 Specifically all Trust staff must:
Participate in training on how to safeguard and promote the welfare of children;
Be alert to potential indicators of abuse or neglect in children;
Work effectively and liaise with professionals within the Trust and other partner agencies;
Remain professionally updated regarding safeguarding issues;
Work within the guidance from their relevant professional regulatory body.
4.8.3 Trust staff members who work predominantly or completely with adults who have parental responsibilities share a commitment to safeguard and promote the welfare of the child.
Duties of Clinical Bank and Agency Staff Working for the Trust

The MSE group is committed to professionally developing clinical bank and agency staff to take an active professional role in child protection. This development is facilitated through training and regular supervision:
Staff are expected to work within safe parameters and the NMC Code of Conduct;
To liaise with the appropriate agencies in the identification of suspected physical abuse, sexual abuse, emotional abuse and neglect and the assessment of children in need;
Bank and agency staff must work to the Trust's policies and procedures.
It is also the responsibility of the practitioner to professionally update on child protection issues and to attend mandatory and relevant study days.

Managers and Team Leaders will be responsible for monitoring the actions of their staff to safeguard and promote the welfare of children via access to supervision and personal development reviews. Children will be listened to appropriately and concerns expressed about their or any other child's welfare are taken seriously and responded to in an appropriate manner.
Management of Children Not Brought to Appointments (Process)
Routine Patients Who “Was Not Brought” (WNB) to an Outpatient/ Diagnostic Appointment

The Medway/ Lorenzo/CPIS system will have markers for children to identify children for whom there are known safeguarding concerns by the addition of an alert category. Staff should ensure effective documentation of non- attendance of appointments and action taken in the child's record / electronic record
New Patients
First Non-Attendance
The child's Consultant is responsible for further management of the child's appointments.
The Consultant will review whether further appointments will be offered.
If not, a letter will be sent to the child's GP/referrer and family.
If a second non-attendance occurs the Consultant will review the case and choose one of the following:

Where the child is under the care of a Consultant and has been referred directly to an Allied Health Professionals Clinic e.g. physiotherapist or occupational therapist but fails to attend – the health professional is responsible for informing the Consultant involved in the child's care.

If no further appointment is to be offered the child should be referred back to the referrer as soon as possible to enable the referrer to make an up to date assessment of the child's needs and decide on the most appropriate next course of action.

Where a child has been referred directly to a Nurse Specialist clinic and is not under the care of a Consultant but the child fails to attend, the Nurse Specialist must refer the missed appointment back to the referrer for further management. The referrer must be informed that a fresh referral may be required for any further appointment/review.

Where a child has been referred directly to an Allied Health Professional and is not under the care of a Consultant but the child fails to attend, the health professional must refer the child back to the referrer for further management. The referrer must be informed that a fresh referral will be required for any further appointment/review.

5.2.1 The 18 week rule does not distinguish between adults and children. However the Trust Patient Access Policy protects the clinical interests of children by ensuring that the responsible clinician is always consulted before any decision is taken to discharge patients from the waiting list.
Follow up Appointments/Patients
Follow up patients who are not brought to their OPD appointment will be offered in

line with the organisations Patient Access Policy if clinically indicated. The consequence of a further non-attendance must be made clear to the child's family in writing (included in the appointment letter). If another appointment is not clinically indicated, a letter will be sent to GP and parents informing them of this.

5.3.1 If the patient is not brought to their second OPD appointment should refer to the organisations Patient Access Policy. The Consultant/Health Professional should communicate with to the GP/referrer and make a clinical judgement as to:-
5.3.2 Practitioners should consider the following to assess whether neglectful parenting is an issue:
Was the appointment previously agreed to by the parent?
Have there been previous unattended appointments?
Are there concerns with regard to other aspects of the child's care?
Is there a pattern of poor engagement by the parent?
Is there a history of Emergency Department attendances?
Have the parents presented the child to out of hours GP services frequently?
Could the non-attendance lead to detrimental effects on the child's health?
Has there been a pattern of missed appointments in relation to other children in the family?
Is the child/young person choosing not to attend?
Is access denied by the parents or access gained to the parent and home but the child unseen?
Are there external factors which affect attendance at the appointment such as lack of transport, poor health of parent, needs of other children within the family or financial restraints?
5.3.3 Staff should follow guidance in attached risk assessment. (Refer to Appendix 1)
Management of Looked After Children

It is recognised that Looked after Children often experience greater difficulty accessing appropriate health services – it is important that outpatient services are readily available and easily accessible to ensure equality in health provision for such children.
Outpatient/ward/administration staff needs to ensure appointments are forwarded to the appropriate Social Worker and foster carer.

Outpatient/ward staff need to ensure foster carer contact details, telephone numbers and address, remain confidential from the parents who may well be attending the appointment with the carer and/or Social Care professional.

If a ‘Looked After Child' fails to attend an outpatient appointment, in addition to informing the Social Worker, GP and Health Visitor/School Nurse, please inform the Safeguarding Children Team who can liaise with the Designated Looked After Children Nurse who is responsible for overseeing the health needs of all
Looked After Children.
Management of Child in Need or Child Who Has a Child Protection Plan / Child in Need Plan

When children who are known to be the subject of a Child Protection Plan/Child In Need Plan fail to attend appointments it is required that staff inform the Paediatric Liaison Health Visitor and GP as applicable and then follow the organisation's Patient Access Policy as appropriate.
5.5.1  Staff caring for the child can contact the social worker directly to discuss their concerns if needed.
Patients/Carers Who Cancel an Outpatient Appointment

If a patient/carer contacts the Hospital to reschedule their child's outpatient appointment, the Trust will make every effort to reschedule their appointment within an appropriate timescale at the convenience of the child and their parent/carer.
5.6.1 If the Child's Parent Cancels an Appointment in Advance on More than Two Occasions:-
The child's Consultant/Health Professional will be responsible for further management of the child's appointment.
5.6.2 If the Child's Parent Cancels an Appointment at Short Notice
First short notice cancellation - will be offered second OPD appointment.
If second appointment is cancelled with short notice the MSE Patient Access Policy should be followed to determine provision of future appointing.
5.6.3 The outcome being either:

Specific training on this policy's implementation into practice is not considered necessary.

The policy will be subject to approval at both the Integrated Child and Adult Safeguarding Committee and the Site Operational Safeguarding Committees.

It is the responsibility of each department to ensure that where manual copies of documents are kept and relied upon that these are always up to date and that the old version is routinely removed. The policy will be accessible on the Staffnet. The policy will be promoted through relevant internal meetings, MSE communications and signposted within safeguarding training.
Equality Impact Assessment
This Policy has been the subject of an Equality Impact Assessment. The output of the assessment demonstrates that no-one, as a consequence of this Policy, is placed at a disadvantage over others.

The MSE Hospitals Group accepts that to accommodate the needs of the increasingly diverse community it serves it must ensure the highest levels of awareness and understanding of equality and diversity amongst its staff.

The MSE Hospitals Group aims to deliver healthcare services that are equitable and are appropriate to each service user's need regardless of age, disability, race, ethnic origin, gender, religion, belief, sexual orientation or domestic circumstances.
Access to services can be affected by a lack of familiarity with health services, the ability to speak English, cultural practices, expectations and other factors.
Where access is identified as an issue the referrer should be contacted to find out how best to facilitate access.
For example:
Use of appropriate first language.
Consideration given to alternative locations for service delivery.
Ensure appointment was clearly communicated to the client.
Appropriate chaperoning available if required.

Appendix 2:
Child Was Not Brought to Appointments (WNB), No Access Visits and Missing Risk Assessment

As children are under the care of adults, the responsibility for attendance at appointments rests with the carer. Non-attendance at appointments may be an indicator of child welfare concerns; therefore a child not brought to appointments should receive special consideration. This includes cancelled appointments and non-attended appointments. This procedure has been developed in regard to a child not being bought to a medical appointment; when health care professionals are unable to gain access for a planned home visit and for managing cases where a child/ newborn baby is unseen at any planned home visit or any other place.

In order to promote the safety and wellbeing of all children and young people, it is vital that failure to attend and no access is considered seriously and the thought of a missing child is not ruled out. Anyone whose whereabouts cannot be established and where circumstances are out of character must be risk assessed. Any additional information and/or circumstances known to coexist with the current difficulty, which may exacerbate risk can be greatly varied and must be considered.

WNB/No Access must be assessed in context of what is known about the child and family and the pattern of engagement. If there are recurrent non-attendance or inconsistent patterns of engagement resulting in the child's health needs not being met, assessment of the impact on the child/baby should be made. Contact should be made with the hospital safeguarding team and supervision should be sought to consider further action.
Identifying risk is essential when dealing with a WNB/No Access contact and each case will require individual consideration, however risk can be assessed using the following:

Low/Medium risk: might be considered for children/young people/pregnant women with a stable condition/situation or where there are no known concerns. This may be considered for families who are known to engage with services generally.

High risk: will be all children/young people/pregnant women who require assessment/intervention to prevent permanent or serious deterioration of their condition or that of the unborn child, or for whom there is risk of significant harm as a result of non-attendance. It is essential to consider all children/young people/pregnant woman who are known to Children's Social Services or those subject to a child protection plan.
Always seek advice from your named/ specialist professional if you have any concerns about a child or family.
Risks of non-attendance are generally described as risks to well-being. These WNB/No access contacts can be looked at in 5 steps:
1- Reflection and review: consider whether the appointment is necessary and the child's

health needs are being met; review records and other data to check address and contact details are correct and ascertain level of risk; consider making a referral to Children's Social Care if deemed to be high risk.
2- Direct interaction with the family; offer another appointment; attempt to make contact with
the family
3- Indirect interaction with the family; attempt to contact wider family members
4- Liaison with internal colleagues: seek advice from safeguarding leads in own organisation
5- External referral: liaise with other professionals outside own organisation, assess risk,
consider referral to MASH
